lol, dude come on that'sÂ EC 101...lol Dividends are paid out from profits.

David Williams Â Companies which are operating at a current loss, for example profitable for the last several years and unprofitable this quarter may still pay a dividend. Dividends are paid from shareholder equity which in turn is increased/decreased by profitability.  It is important to understand that dividends provides shareholders cash at the cost of their equity.

The dividend itself is set by the board based upon any factors they chose.  The publicly quoted dividend rate is calculated from the current price your dividend return rate is calculated from your cost.  Consider a large company will have millions of shareholders, each with one or more purchase price; their initial purchase, additional purchases, dividend reinvestment,Â  some shares are kept in the owners name others in their brokerageÂ  house's name. So while calculating a dividend rate from each individual's cost basis is valuable to you, it is neither practical nor valuable to the public.
Are you talking about common or preferred shares
Erick Palacios Which ever shares the dividends are being paid against. Usually common.

There is no way you will earn compound interest by buying and holding a bond. When he means compound interest, he really means you will have to manage or have someone manage your investment account that actively buys and sells stocks or bonds etc.

RSvideoedittingÂ How about some of Vanguard's index funds (if you're in the U.S.) or index tracking ETFs (if you're not)? Generally, you shouldn't hope for a smooth "continuous" compounding. With any stock-based investment it's going to be more like +30% one year and -20% another year. But if you invest regularly (rather than once at an unlucky peak of a bull market) and hold the stuff long enough, historically you should get a nice average compounded interest rate (of about 7-8%). As a young person, you should also keep your expenses to an absolute minimum to take best advantage of the compounding. Basically, understand that every dollar you spend today won't earn you anything tomorrow. The younger you are, the longer you can earn by avoiding (consumer) spending.

Well it's a litttle complicated. First off, when ever the company decides to give out dividends, it basically calculates it as a "per share amount". So for example $1 per share. That means, if you own 500 shares, that's $500, regardless if you own 1/3 or 1/3000 if the business. Secondly, dividends are not a cost because dividends come from the profits of the business. The profits of the company can either be A:reinvested B:cashed out to shareholders(dividends). russell schaefflerÂ I believe it's fairly common knowledge.  There are two ways of improving business: by reducing risks or by increasing expected gains. The skill of a businessman consists in being able to do both.  The risk part is done either by hiring other people with special skills who are able to avoid the risks from materializing or at least to deal with their consequences. Unfortunately, high-skilled people are generally not dumb to sell themselves cheap, perhaps to the point that the venture is not any longer profitable if you want to have them. So, generally it's more convenient and may cost less to find someone (preferably deep-pocketed) that would agree to bear the burden of risk for you and dumb/adventurous/desperate enough to not demand full return on his capital. Failing that, you can also try shifting the risk on society at large (and possibly face punishment when they catch up to your tricks).  The key lesson is you cannot make risk disappear, but you need to do something about it and first and foremost you should not keep it to yourself (see above; risk-handling is better left to well-paid, highly skilled professionals and rich investors, not enthusiastic entrepreneurs).  That's even proper when judged from a left-wing perspective because it harms the "evil greedy capitalists" in a way by pulling out money out of their fat pockets and forcing them to contribute back to society. From a right-wing perspective one would also add that there is no need for any further mechanisms of redistribution, as the redistribution already happens by means of capitalism.

If you look at the cash flow statement at 8:17, then he shows you how he ends up with the $500 needed for the next lemonade stand. Two things in here people might question is: 1) using the after tax ($10), instead of the pre-tax ($15) lost. Based on 5:41 cash flow statement after 1st year, he get $5 tax credit, so he is using that number. 2) he doesn't need additional $200 cash inventory for the already operating 1st store, because of accrual accounting meaning business like people could buy inventory on credit cards and don't pay the $200 till later especially if they established good relationship with suppliers, and been operating for a year. He can even do the same 2nd stand in that case he would need less than $500 to open next stand.

Joking aside, a "bail-out" is not a gift of free money but normally involves the Govt buying preferred shares for a non-trivial amount of interest, which reduces the net profit.  You need the cash-flow statement in addition to the balance sheet and P & L. That way you can strip out the intangibles like "goodwill". Truly a good clip to watch and learn from. Definitely a basics video however, I wish he would of went into a little more detail of what it was going to cost to set up that lemonade stand. Had Mr. Ackman published all up front start up costs the lemonade stand would have never got off the ground. There are maintenance costs over the next 5 years on the existing stands to keep them in good standing. This could include paint, new boards, missing screws. Then there is the licensing required by city's to operate a business in a certain location. Rent on the land to have the lemonade stand. Obviously there was no purchasing of a spot to place the stand. The startup cost was merely to buy the stand. Not the location it was to be placed. Insurance to protect our investment against acts of nature, vandalism, or illness' brought on by "bad" lemonade in the event of a law suit. Last but not least is the percentage of spoilage. Lemons that go bad. Partial jugs of lemonade not served at the end of the day but cannot be saved and have to be dumped to comply with safe consumption federal laws.Â   In no way shape or form am I criticizing Mr. Ackman. He did mention again it was a basics video. I just wish that more of these details had been put into the original scenario to make the original start up look closer to real life practices and give a more meaningful ending.Â   Thanks. :-)

Because the investor put up $500 for one third (33%) of the company. If $500= 33% of the company, then 100% of the company would be worth $1500. That process is called valuation.
at 1:50 he explains it...Â  you bring in $1000 because you own 67% of the company and the other guy $500 for 33% and 250 you got from a friend...

In real life they really do make make up a number in the balance sheet, Its called goodwill. It's basically a measurement of the companies synergy in a sense. For example when you put together some wood to make a house, the house is worth a lot more than the cost of the wood to make it. So that extra value is measured as good will on the balance sheet

canimakeamillÂ No good person could say someone who are willing to learn a dumbass. After all, we are all ignorant first before knowing something. Yeah, there are some guys calling people dumbass all over internet but that says what kind of people they are...

*****Â What happens in real life is that the actual money used to build the company is from borrowing or investment. So the actual amount that we have above is $750. The $1000 dollars are just magically assumed to be the value that we bring along.Â   As someone explained above if we offer 33% of our business to the investor and he gives us $500 then it automatically means that we have bought in the remaining 67% which works out to $1000. This is because we want to control the company.  The actual rate that we get and the actual value will be determined when we actually sell the company. The share value is in fact a pseudo value.

*****Â Book value of a company does not equal its market value, which does not equal available cash at hand. The $1000 in book value is what the accountant recorded to account for the 66%/33% ownership stakes.  Of it only $500 exists in form of available cash, the $1000 constituting the remaining book value is more or less fantasy (and therefore called "goodwill").  The market value of the business would be what someone else would be willing to pay for it. It might be less or more than $1500, depending on whether they are more skeptical or more enthusiastic about the future prospects than the current owners.  The important thing to remember is that things do not really have any "intrinsic" value. Rather, everyone may come up with their own price of something; the price will only be realized if someone else agrees with them (which is very unlikely to happen if they can a better deal elsewhere - which is why market prices for some well-defined good or service tend to be quite uniform).  You could argue that the $500 cash has an intrinsic value - it's worth exactly $500 after all. Obviously, it is true in a shallow sense, as long as you stick to using dollars as a metric of value. However, if you consider that $500 can buy you an X amount of stuff today and Y amount of stuff tomorrow, you realize that even cash has no stable value - it's an asset just like others, the value of which fluctuates relatively to other assets. This relative value comes from demand, which apart from common use comes from the fact that you cannot pay taxes or obtain any public services using any other asset (which you'd have to sell for cash first).

It's assumed he just convinced the investor to value it at $1500. That's a conversation they already had.  An investor is going to want to give the entrepreneur a large stake in shareholders' equity so the entrepreneur is motivated by the "carrot". Eg look at Brad Feld's notes on VC for more discussion on this.

You should review your accounting textbooks. The company might have recorded a net loss, but it had positive cash flow. Think about what expenses were recorded the first year and determine if they were actually cash expenses (depreciation). Incorrect, he does not have 750.  He spent 300(as he shows), but he adds the depreciation as if it were income, which it is not.  Really he has 440 to put back into the company after year 1, not 500.  Same depreciation fallacy each year, so year 2 ends with 230 in cash, not 411, year 3 is 225, not 586, year 4 is 542, not 1143, year 5 is 1144, not 2165.  Also, after year 5, the first stand has fully depreciated, so he has 6 stands, not 7.

Again, on Income statement sheet, there is no inclusion of the initial money borrowed. in that list of assets you mention, he subtracts costs of inventory and fixed assets from the money borrowed. On the income statement sheet he subtracts the same thing from the REVENUE and leaves out the money borrowed. He does not have to subtract those things twice. Therefore, mathematically, he still has 750 to plug into the equation.

Except that isn't accurate.  He showed a list of assets near the beginning wherein that 750 in cash was turned into 250 cash +inventory+static assets.  So by showing a loss for that first year, he had -less- than 250 to work with to reinvest into the business for the next year, which is less than the cost he assigned to the purchase of a stall(300), much less the cost of -buying- the new inventory for any stalls(200 per).  So to grow, he would have been forced to take on more debt.

Are you familiar with the concept of saving? Do you think it's a silly thing to do? Do you think it's bad? I think saving is great. I forfeit a certain amount of resources owed to me to someone else for a while, so that they can, instead of simply consuming resources, create more resources than there were before, by making better use of existing resources. The interest you gain on your savings is possible because value is added to the economy when you lend entrepreneurs your money.

Depriving yourself of money and allowing a firm to make better use of it?  That's just a fancy way of saying "doing nothing," as suomi22 said.  I'd add to that by saying you need to be rich in first place, and then do nothing.

The company had $750 - $300 fixed asset - $200 inventory so it had beginning cash of $250 the company then generated (800-200-530-25)=$45 (5:39) in operating cash flow $250+$45=$295 ending cash.  Unless the business gets $5 tax refund in (7:42), which makes no sense because its the business' first year of operating. so should be not be able to carry the loss back against past taxes paid, then it would have $300, but would have no money for inventory.
^ this > 4 years of college

Also, it's not gaining money from "doing nothing", it's gaining money from depriving yourself of the money. When you invest $10,000, you can't buy new plant machinery for $10,000, but the firm you invested in now can. Why does your money grow? Because the firm you invested in makes better use of the machinery than you ever could, because they have the resources to efficiently use the capital you provided (=the machine) gather more resources, and you are entitled to the extra resources gathered.

Ethical investment is not rational, unless the ethics aspect is a strategic aspect of the business that gives it an advantage over its competition, but nearly every company today engages in some sort of token "social responsibility". All Ackman does here is provide with you with some guidelines for creating a stock portfolio with the goal of a very long term investment at roughly the market rate of return - probably one of the sanest thing you can do if you decide to play the stock market game.
